Can you please do the following:
1. Sync your branch with latest trunk (there are a bunch of merge conflicts because your branch is not update to date with trunk) - https://libcloud.readthedocs.org/en/latest/development.html#syncing-your-git-hub-repository-with-an-official-upstream-git-repository
2. Squash all the commits into one

Thanks, this looks like a good start, but it should be changed to match other drives and use a generator approach. This means implementing `iterate_zones` and `iterate_records` method.

`list_zones` and `list_records` doesn't need to be implemented in this case since it's already provided by a parent class.

You can find an example of how Zerigo driver does that here - https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/dns/drivers/zerigo.py#L149
Also needs a test case for a size without `diskofferingid` attribute.

I was talking to someone recently (@jnoller, I think) about writing up some long-running integration-style tests to catch this type of thing, since it has bitten us a bunch on the pyrax project as well. Another thing to add to the todo list!

@briancurtin, @jnoller Yeah, having integration tests would definitely be nice.

When people originally started to work on tests, they had this idea in mind so they made all the credentials pluggable (`secres.py-dist`). The idea was that you could just put in real provider credentials and the tests would run against a live installation.

Sadly that's easier said than done. A lot of tests for edge cases rely on an account being in specific state which means they won't work against a live installation. Making tests work against a live installation, would at this point, require a substantial amount of work with changes to the existing tests.

One thing we could do is use a more gradual approach and start working on a separate integration test suite. This way we would have two independent test suites (unit & integration). With this approach we might trade long term overhead of maintaining two test suites for short term flexibility and speed, but it's probably worth it.

Perhaps it would be good to add get_key_pair? There could be a default implementation using list_key_pairs. It would raise KeyPairNotFound if there is no such key pair.

Also, a KeyPairAlreadyExists exception for the create and import API's would be good.

@Jc2k Yeah, I was thinking about that as well. All the new APIs expose "get one" functionality (storage, dns) so it also makes sense to add a `get_key_pair` method here.

I just checked the API docs and all of the APIs (EC2, CloudStack, OpenStack) support retrieving information for a single key pair so we don't need to use a potentially expensive list_key_pairs.
@Jc2k As far as the exception name goes, I was thinking about `ZoneDoesNotExist` since other APIs also use `DoesNotExist` suffix.
I guess you meant `KeyPairDoesNotExist` - I was thinking of the DNS exceptions too, but misremembered. +1 for following what we do there.
Yeah, sorry, I meant `KeyparDoesNotExist` :)
@Jc2k `get_key_pair` and related changes implemented in c62c472b0887077ef3402ace51adb511e2b3cf60.

I was having issues also trying to run the tests on `python2.5`, because I can no longer install the development packages for that version of Python (in order to pull all of it's dependencies).

I've resolved the `AtmosTests` failure, I'm a bit unsure where those hash errors in the Rackspace provider are coming from, they have strange results... I'll have a look at that.
I've resolved the Rackspace test failures now, this seems to because of checking response hashes in it's Content-Type failure tests.  Because the behaviour is now different, I've updated this test.

@micolous I've made some changes, squashed your commits and merged patch into trunk.

The changes I've made include:
- Added and exported a `DEFAULT_CONTENT_TYPE` constant (888b3d598ee0d67cea6ec899d1aa1ec330dd36c4)
- Added a test case for default content type being specified (888b3d598ee0d67cea6ec899d1aa1ec330dd36c4)
- Added a strict mode which defaults to `False`. If strict mode is used, old behavior is preserved and exception will be thrown if no content type is provided and none be detected. (ec90fcb8a32f5e4a0330ffa6d7b932b65bc82077)
- Updated upgrade notes (0e8c2f06e2b6c1ca245f86000471563d4aaeaa79)

It appears paramiko just tries different authentication methods in a pre-defined order of priority so this change looks good.

I am not sure what you mean by 'has a method delete which doesn't work' ? what exactly does not work ? you did not seem to modify that method.

Also what do you mean by "change call signature...' 

Ok to rename ex_add_ip_forwarding_rule to ex_create_ip_frowarding_rule, but we will have to keep track of the fact this will break backward compatibility.

ex_create_port_forwarding_rule was:

``` python
def ex_create_port_forwarding_rule(self, address, private_port,
                                       public_port, protocol, node,
                                       public_end_port=None,
                                       private_end_port=None,
                                       openfirewall=True):
```

Now it:

``` python
def ex_create_port_forwarding_rule(self, node, address,
                                       private_port, public_port,
                                       protocol,
                                       public_end_port=None,
                                       private_end_port=None,
                                       openfirewall=True):
```

Because in all methods argument 'node' in first place.

About method delete:
Class CloudStackPortForwardingRule has method delete, it call self.node.ex_delete_port_forwarding_rule(self), but CloudstackNode doesn't has a method ex_delete_port_forwarding_rule - I fix this.

Ok, I'm rename method and fix test.

@runseb While reviewing this pull request I noticed a couple of unrelated issues in the driver.

`ex_allocate_public_ip` and `ex_release_public_ip` method on the `CloudStackNode` class seems to be broken.

Both of those methods call methods on the driver class with invalid arguments. They pass `node` object to the driver method, but the driver method doesn't take a node object.

See:
- https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/compute/drivers/cloudstack.py#L39 
- https://github.com/apache/libcloud/blob/trunk/libcloud/compute/drivers/cloudstack.py#L828

We have two options:
1. Fix those methods to actually do what the docstring says - allocate the IP **and bind it to the node**
2.  Remove those methods from the `CloudStackNode` class since in the current form, they don't belong there.

We also need better test coverage to detect issues like this automatically in the future.

Edit: I've opened a JIRA issue for it - https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/LIBCLOUD-462. We can move this off topic debate there.
